Change to Title. Changed title from Partnership Control System (PCS) to Pass-Through Control System (PCS). PCS is used to manage S-corporations as well as partnerships. Pass-through control is more reﬂective of the systems function.

Editorial changes throughout. Updated terminology used, and removed italics from titles. Changed Campus TEFRA Function (CTF) to Campus Pass-through Function (CPF) where appropriate. Some references to CTF remain as PCS programming has not yet changed. Spelled out ﬁrst use of acronyms.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This material supersedes IRM 4.29.4, dated 11/27/2017. Changes to this IRM will also affect the Pass- Through Entity Handbook, IRM 4.31 Sections 1 through 8. That IRM is currently being rewritten and will include the changes contained in this IRM.
AUDIENCE
Field and campus personnel working TEFRA and ILSC pass-through entities and/or their investors.
Table of Contents
) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) section provides an explanation of reports generated from the Pass-through Control System (PCS) database. and (
) Purpose: This IRM is to describe the use and basic guidelines for PCS generated reports. (
) Audience: Field Examination Revenue Agents (RAs) and campus RAs, Compliance Offers (TCOs), Tax Examiners (TEs) and Clerks working through entities and/or their investors linked on PCS. (
) Policy Owner: Director, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), ters, Examination Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP) (
) Program Owner: Program Manager, Campus Examination and Field (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) (
) Primary Stakeholders: SB/SE, Large Business and Industry (LB&I), and Appeals (

) Program Goals: PCS is a database used to create an electronic linkage between pass-through entities and their underlying partners. Linking in instances is mandatory. Linkage allows for the proper control of statutes ensures all relevant partners are processed. (
) Contact Information: To recommend changes or make any other related to this IRM section, see IRM
, Providing Feedback About IRM Section - Outside of Clearance. (

) PCS was created to monitor and control pass-through entity investors. through entities can have many partners and many levels of tiering. occurs when an investor in a pass-through entity is also a pass-through This complexity can make it difficult to keep track of statutes and monitor the investors. (

) PCS control is a policy that was established in response to the provisions of the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act (TEFRA) of has been expanded to cover other pass-through entities that fall outside TEFRA. (

) The Director, SB/SE, Headquarters, Examination Field and Campus (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP) is responsible for: or a. Coordinating and implementing PCS enhancements; b. Coordinating resolutions for PCS systemic problems; and c. Updating this Handbook. (

) The SB/SE Program Manager, Examination Field and Campus Policy, Exam & Field Support (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) is responsible for: a. Ensuring that PCS procedural changes and computer program are implemented and coordinated with area office and campus tion personnel; and b. Monitoring and evaluating area office and campus examination PCS quality control procedures. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Policy Owner: Director, Small Business/Self-Employed (SB/SE), Headquar- ters, Examination Field and Campus Policy (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP)
The SB/SE Program Manager, Examination Field and Campus Policy, Campus Exam & Field Support (SE:S:E:HQ:EFCP:CEFS) is responsible for:

Ensuring that PCS procedural changes and computer program are implemented and coordinated with area office and campus tion personnel; and Monitoring and evaluating area office and campus examination PCS quality control procedures.

Pass-Through Control Field Territory Managers, Field Area Directors, Director over LB&I Ogden Director, Examination - Brookhaven, are responsible for ensuring that: a. An accurate database is established by designating PCS and activities; and b. A PCS quality control system is implemented. This includes timely on PCS record establishments, PCS reports, and AIMS TC

Reject Registers. It also includes timely processing of TEFRA notices and Appeals settlement letters (campus only). Area office Examination Managers and campus Field Support Operations managers are responsible for: a. Maintaining an updated copy of IRM

, Pass-Through Control (PCS) Handbook, in their respective functions; b. Ensuring the training of technical and clerical employees in PCS dures; and c. Establishing PCS records and acting on PCS reports in a timely to assure an accurate PCS database. The campus PCS Coordinator works with: • The other PCS coordinator(s) • Their local employees • Other campus functional areas to ensure timely processing of PCS related activities The campus PCS Coordinator is charged with: • Identifying and resolving technical problems • Identifying and coordinating the resolution of PCS systemic problems Following are speciﬁc campus PCS Coordinator responsibilities: a. Coordinate PCS operations among areas, Campus Pass-through Functions (CPFs), and other campus functions; b. Ensure timely processing and distribution of PCS output; c. Ensure that all requests for establishment and linkage on PCS are reviewed for accuracy, completeness, and timeliness; d. Maintain accuracy of the PCS database by ensuring that action and reports are worked in required time frames; e. Resolve Audit Information Management System (AIMS) problems; f. Assist in the training of examination personnel in PCS procedures and system; g. Establish and update CPF and Appeals parameter ﬁles; h. Review completed Form
, PCS Notice Parameters, prepared by CPF and Appeals; i. Create, load, print, proofread, and edit parameter ﬁle data using Form

, PCS Notice Parameters; j. Coordinate with Computer Systems Analyst (CSA) whenever a change made to parameters; k. Review and input all campus Command Code (CC) Mass Change (MSCHG) and linkage deletion (TSDEL) requests; l. Coordinate requests for PCS IVLs with campus computer services and requesting function.
4.29 Pass-Through Control System
Field Territory Managers, Field Area Directors, Director over LB&I Ogden and Director, Examination - Brookhaven, are responsible for ensuring that:

An accurate database is established by designating PCS responsibilities and activities; and A PCS quality control system is implemented. This includes timely action on PCS record establishments, PCS reports, and AIMS TC
Reject Registers. It also includes timely processing of TEFRA notices and Appeals settlement letters (campus only).

Following are speciﬁc campus PCS Coordinator responsibilities: a. Coordinate PCS operations among areas, Campus Pass-through Functions (CPFs), and other campus functions; b. Ensure timely processing and distribution of PCS output; c. Ensure that all requests for establishment and linkage on PCS are reviewed for accuracy, completeness, and timeliness; d. Maintain accuracy of the PCS database by ensuring that action and reports are worked in required time frames; e. Resolve Audit Information Management System (AIMS) problems; f. Assist in the training of examination personnel in PCS procedures and system; g. Establish and update CPF and Appeals parameter ﬁles; h. Review completed Form
, PCS Notice Parameters, prepared by CPF and Appeals; i. Create, load, print, proofread, and edit parameter ﬁle data using Form

, PCS Notice Parameters; j. Coordinate with Computer Systems Analyst (CSA) whenever a change is made to parameters; k. Review and input all campus Command Code (CC) Mass Change (MSCHG) and linkage deletion (TSDEL) requests; l. Coordinate requests for PCS IVLs with campus computer services and requesting function.

) During centralized processing at MCC, PCS data is input in the database date and time order of input. An input can be accepted during real-time but Error Register, rejected during centralized processing if the accessed record is no longer the Partnership Investor Control File (PICF). (

notiﬁes the key case ﬁeld office or CPF of inputs rejected centralized processing. A literal reject message appears on the report. reject messages are shown in Exhibit
, Error Register Reject The command code originally input, as well as pertinent key case and information, is included on the error register. (
) This error register should be analyzed when received by the PCS to ensure that corrected inputs are made. No action is needed for CC rejects. (

, Deleted Investors, lists investor records dropped from PCS the only key case linkage has been deleted. The key case linkage is on the report to assist contacting the key case ﬁeld office or CPF. (
) The report gives the reason the investor record dropped from the PCS: • CC TSDEL; • Purge-date realized; or •
-drop date realized. The report lists all linkage records that were present when the investor dropped. (
) The investor record and key case record are displayed in the following • The ﬁrst
positions are for an edited TIN; • There are two blank positions, then the next two positions are the code; and • There are two blank positions, then the next six positions are the period. (
) Investor records dropped from the PCS are printed on Report
only They do not repeat on subsequent weekly reports. AIMS records are not affected when the record drops from the PCS. (
) The investor ﬁeld function or CPF must determine whether to re-control the case on the PCS, close the case on AIMS, or leave the case controlled on AIMS, but not on the PCS.

) Investor records with an entry of A, B, C, M, R, or S in the package received indicator ﬁeld are listed on separate report pages. See IRM Exhibit
, Report Package Received Indicator Codes, for the meaning of these codes. Records with MFT code
are also listed on separate report pages. All other IMF investors are listed separately from all other BMF investors. (
) Investor records added to Report
within the prior three PCS cycles are identiﬁed by the literal “NEW” to the extreme right of the report. Records ﬁed as “NEW” are listed at the beginning of each separate sort for the report. (

) The “NEW” investor records are listed in one-year assessment date order followed by all other investor records in one-year assessment statute date order. If an investor has multiple linkages with a one-year date present, the investor and all linkages with a one-year date will be listed on the report by earliest one-year date. (

) An entry of “Y” in the Report Package Received Indicator ﬁeld signiﬁes that investor report writing package was received. Follow-up action must be taken to secure packages that have not been received. (
) TEFRA investor records, with the TEFRA assessment already processed, appear on this report with a “

” one-year assessment statute date. one-year assessment statute date ﬁeld MUST NOT be deleted when the TEFRA assessment is made. If it is deleted the investor record reappears on this report as a new investor requiring action, when a mass change update takes place after the assessment is made. (
) When the TEFRA assessment is made, the one year assessment statute must be updated to “

) If there is an unagreed penalty or affected item issue, the one-year assess- ment statute date must be updated to the six digit numeric date followed by (YYYYMMDDP) with CC TSCHG. The one-year date for the penalty or item issue will be updated to “
” when the penalty or affected item is assessed. (
) One-year assessment statute dates that have been updated to “

of CC TSCHG. a. This will allow subsequent one-year assessment statute dates to pass- through to the tier investors, and it retains accomplishments from the investor report. b. ) This report lists tier partnerships that have not been perfected. An tier is one that does not have a tier indicator of “#” or “X”. The CPF should Tier Report, work this report timely to ensure that all tiers partners are linked, or that the tier should be a ’no-load’. These unperfected partnerships must be perfected on the system to maintain adequate control of inventory. (

This report lists tier partnerships that have not been perfected. An unperfected tier is one that does not have a tier indicator of “#” or “X”. The CPF should work this report timely to ensure that all tiers partners are linked, or determine that the tier should be a ’no
load’. These unperfected partnerships must be perfected on the system to maintain adequate control of inventory.
6-8, TEFRA Investor Returns/TEFRA Investor Count, totals returns by ﬁeld office, and special project code.
Report 6-8(N), NonTEFRA Investor Returns/NonTEFRA Investor Count, totals returns by campus/PTE, ﬁeld office, and special project code.
Report 8-1, Number of NonTEFRA CTF Investor Returns by Tax Period, returns in employee group codes 54XX, if they have only ILSC linkages.
Report 8-3, TEFRA Assessments, totals TEFRA assessments, overassess- ments, and no-changes by dollars and counts.

The information on the report reﬂects the assessment amounts input by the CPFs via CC TSCHG when a partial assessment or a full closure is made to an investor account. The amount of the assessment is input along with the “
” in the one-year assessment statute date ﬁeld.
The program will only include the last amount input for a given linkage during the weekly reporting cycle. The report also provides year
to
date accomplishments, report writing inventory, and suspensed investor returns.

4.29 Pass-Through Control System

) The run controls contains various counts of records processed by the programs. These counts include the number of records in the input ﬁle read the program (a INPUT-COUNT); a count of how many records the program bypasses instead of processing (a BYPASS-COUNT); how many records that are not bypassed but contain an error (an ERROR-COUNT); and how many records that are not bypassed (processed) and are considered valid (a COUNT). (

) The different programs usually check the values of certain ﬁelds in a record determine whether or not a record is added to the different counts. For example, the Primary Business Code (PBS) is checked for certain values. If the value matches one of the speciﬁed values, the valid count is recorded. If the campus that controls the partner record (PN) isn’t Ogden or Brookhaven, then the record is added to the error count. (
) The bypassed records count is a count of records whose LN-PN-TEFRA-CD not a space (i.e., a TEFRA case) or if the PBC-PTR ﬁeld is not equal to
) The valid records count are those records whose PBC-PTR ﬁeld doesn’t

) The error count is those records whose PBC and service center code are not valid combination. (
) The bypassed records count includes those records whose LN-
-YR-ASSMT- DATE has either spaces or zeroes as values. It also includes those records whose ASSESSMENT-DATE is more than
days in the past. (
) The valid records count are those records whose BOD-PBC doesn’t contain certain values (

) and the APPL-BOD and PN-CTF-IND are “B”. (
) The error count is those records whose PN-CTF-IND is not either “B” or “O” (Brookhaven or Ogden). (

) The bypassed records count include those records whose LN-PN-TEFRA-CD is not “T” (i.e., an ILSC case). Also included in the count are those records whose pass-through record key (PS-KEY) is not the same as the previous record’s PS-KEY. Those records which do not meet the criteria for a valid record (see below) are also added to the bypassed count. (
